review_title: Highly emotional and erratic management who is unqualified to be in a leadership role.
job_title: Academic Advisor in Daytona Beach, FL
pros:
There are cheap benefits.
Hour-long lunch.
Nothing else.
cons:
I originally turned down the job but later decided to take the job to get out of a tough situation. I’ll admit it was a stop-gap solution, but I regret the decision I made. A person in management is irritable, erratic, and is constantly marching around the office like a 5-year-old child. The person was not present within the department that is, they weren't really a part of Academic Advising but rather more of a marketing person, trying to increase funding that goes to Academic Advising year-to-year through “initiatives”. All the new employees joked about things this person would do and say, they would yell from their office to other colleagues and their mood was constantly changing from one hour to the next and people would have to tell the person to “calm down”. I have no idea why they put this person in charge of Academic Advising; I think it was one of those things where they just promoted someone who had been there for a long time. An unsettling trend in academia is it’s not about skill but about “yes” men. There was a person in management who was ok and we considered the real person in chargee and ran most of the integral aspects of Academic Advising, the only problem was kissing the behind of others above them.  The dual enrollment coordinator hated their job.

Academic Advising was run in a way where you wouldn’t just have to know Academic Advising, but admissions, financial aid, accounts, records, and dual enrollment. They wanted you to advise on every aspect of the college while they offered you an underwhelming 35.6k a year which is $17.12 an hour. They would constantly say a strength of Daytona State College was that you could switch departments but that’s because they have everyone doing someone else’s work. Some of the issues that came up were unclear expectations for the employees and lack of support. It was impossible to know what was expected. When you thought you were doing what you were supposed to, you weren’t, and vice-versa. Issues would arise within the department the manager would never give a firm answer to a resolution, and would just blow it off and ignore it. Another thing I hated was the manager's “side-projects” they would increase the workload on employees for the sake of being trendy to secure more money for the department. The employees were miserable, everyone talked about the low pay and the environment was average at best.

A little add-on about another higher member of the company in upper management who wasn't liked by anyone creeped everyone out and had a serious case of big ego-small results. This person was known as the suit-person every day and wouldn’t acknowledge you unless he needed something. This person would make silly comments in meetings, to show how important and powerful they was, and I think this was again a case of promoting someone who really shouldn’t have been promoted. 

Overall skip this place, the management sucks, the pay is terrible, there is no room for advancement and the employees who stay there for a long time are left thankless. Don’t burn yourself it’s not worth it.

review_title: It was a very positive environment

job_title: in Daytona Beach, FL
pros:
Very economical school, was Daytona Beach Community College until the availability of Federal funds led them to change to a "State" college.
People for the most part are friendly and helpful.
cons:
This is a small town school with lots of politics.  If you say the wrong thing to the wrong person it will come back to bite you.
Because this is such a small campus, there are a lot of close friendships between individuals in different departments.  Be careful who you complain about.
The procedures and processes in place to get anything accomplished are basically nonexistent.  It can take weeks or months to get results from even the smallest request to upper management.  They are very heavy on the paperwork side with almost no computerized solutions for small things such as travel / faculty reimbursements.  The systems that are in place are cumbersome and hard to navigate.

job_title: Financial Aid Specialist in Daytona Beach, FL
pros:
Benefits (not including pay) are good and hours are stable. 
Great teachers.
cons: I have never encountered such inadequate supervisors and administrators. This small-town college is a trap-door. Bureaucracy doesn’t even begin to describe this place of employment. DSC is a direct reflection of how backwards the government and politics in Volusia county are. If you are not a friend of an administrator or a friend of a wealthy contributor then you are very un-likely to get a job here at DSC; no matter how qualified you may be or how many years of experience you may possess. This small groups of administrators are so tightly knitted that even if by the grace of God you were offered a job there is little to no chance of excelling.  Inappropriate friendships as well as a lack of communication between all departments and within most departments seem to be the theme here at DSC. Use this job as a resume builder and keep it moving. The politics here will eat you alive. Document everything because that is just how nasty things can get at DSC.

review_title: Poor Management with favoritism of other employees

job_title: Coordinator in Daytona Beach, FL
pros: No micro-management whatsoever because no one really cared what you were doing.  No "overtime" ever required. Lots of time off.  Some colleagues really nice.  If you like a slow pace and being able to do other work while on the job (which I didn't prefer), this is the place for you.
cons: Low pay, empty promises, difficult to advance unless you are in the upper election, difficult faculty, upper management receiving raises while everyone else suffered through a freeze on raises. Employees treated very differently; the lower level the employee, the worse they are treated.

job_title: Private in Daytona Beach, FL
pros: 3 weeks' paid vacation on top of public holidays. Health & fitness facilities.  Annual preventive health care gives peace of mind.  Reduced-price quality lunches/dinners provided by students in the hospitality college program.
cons: Management was top-heavy, but may have changed since I left.  Poverty line salaries for support staff.  Prepare to have your embarrassingly low salary printed in the local paper for any one to see. Demoralizing.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Palm Coast, FL

cons: Volusia/Flagler are two of the lowest-paid counties in FL, which is reflected in the abysmally low salaries for support staff.

It's amateur night in Dixie Land working for the higher level administration.
